questions.question_text_1: In which of the following scenarios would you typically choose a microcontroller (MCU) over a microprocessor (MPU)?
question_texts: In which of the following scenarios would you typically choose a microcontroller (MCU) over a microprocessor (MPU)?

options.option_text: Developing a specialized device for monitoring temperature and humidity.
Designing a server for hosting multiple websites.
Creating a software application for financial modeling.

questions.question_text_1: Which programming language is an object-oriented extension of C and is often used in embedded systems for its enhanced features and modularity?
question_texts: Which programming language is an object-oriented extension of C and is often used in embedded systems for its enhanced features and modularity?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following data types would be most memory-efficient for storing the small integer number in an array, given that the maximum value of numbers can be 100?
question_texts: Which of the following data types would be most memory-efficient for storing the small integer number in an array, given that the maximum value of numbers can be 100?

questions.question_text_1: You are using a 10-bit ADC to digitize a signal in the range of 0 to 3.3V. What is the minimum difference (approx) between two voltages that you can measure?
question_texts: You are using a 10-bit ADC to digitize a signal in the range of 0 to 3.3V. What is the minimum difference (approx) between two voltages that you can measure?

questions.question_text_1: Which wireless communication protocol is designed for low-power, short-range communication and is commonly used for home automation and sensor networks?
question_texts: Which wireless communication protocol is designed for low-power, short-range communication and is commonly used for home automation and sensor networks?

questions.question_text_1: What does the scalability of a communication protocol in embedded systems refer to?
question_texts: What does the scalability of a communication protocol in embedded systems refer to?

options.option_text: The protocol’s ability to function in real-time
The protocol’s ability to handle an increasing number of devices efficiently
The protocol’s speed of data transmission
The protocol’s resistance to electromagnetic interference

questions.question_text_1: How does loop unrolling optimize code execution in embedded systems?
question_texts: How does loop unrolling optimize code execution in embedded systems?

options.option_text: By increasing the number of iterations.
By reducing the number of iterations and the overhead of loop control.
By combining multiple loops into one.

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary factor that determines the power consumption in an electronic system when the voltage is constant?
question_texts: What is the primary factor that determines the power consumption in an electronic system when the voltage is constant?

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary purpose of a driver in the context of embedded systems?
question_texts: What is the primary purpose of a driver in the context of embedded systems?

options.option_text: To provide an abstraction layer over hardware components

questions.question_text_1: What is the role of assertions in error handling?
question_texts: What is the role of assertions in error handling?

options.option_text: To catch unexpected conditions during development

questions.question_text_1: What action is performed when a task is deleted?
question_texts: What action is performed when a task is deleted?

options.option_text: Allocating memory for the task stack
Adding the task to the scheduler's ready list

questions.question_text_1: You are designing an embedded system for a real-time audio processing application. The system needs to handle audio data sampled at 48 kHz. The CPU must perform complex signal processing algorithms on the audio data without interruption. How would you use Direct Memory Access (DMA) to optimize the system's performance?
question_texts: You are designing an embedded system for a real-time audio processing application. The system needs to handle audio data sampled at 48 kHz. The CPU must perform complex signal processing algorithms on the audio data without interruption. How would you use Direct Memory Access (DMA) to optimize the system's performance?

options.option_text: Configure the CPU to handle all audio data transfers to ensure real-timeprocessing.

Use DMA to transfer audio data from the ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter) toa memory buffer and generate an interrupt when the buffer is full, allowing the CPU to process the data while DMA continues to handle new data transfers.
Disable DMA and increase the CPU clock speed to handle data transfers andprocessing simultaneously.
Use the CPU to transfer audio data from the ADC to memory and DMA totransfer data from memory to the DAC (Digital-to-Analog Converter).

questions.question_text_1: Which strategy is most effective for reducing leakage currents in an embedded system?
question_texts: Which strategy is most effective for reducing leakage currents in an embedded system?

options.option_text: Implementing sleep modes for unused components

questions.question_text_1: While developing an embedded system for an automotive application, you need to ensure that the system responds to sensor inputs within a strict time frame. What is the most effective way to debug and ensure your system meets these real-time requirements?
question_texts: While developing an embedded system for an automotive application, you need to ensure that the system responds to sensor inputs within a strict time frame. What is the most effective way to debug and ensure your system meets these real-time requirements?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following strategies would be the most effective for using static analysis to enhance the safety and reliability of the drone's RTOS, and why?
question_texts: Which of the following strategies would be the most effective for using static analysis to enhance the safety and reliability of the drone's RTOS, and why?

options.option_text: Use static analysis to generate test cases automatically and execute themduring runtime to identify bugs under real-world conditions.
Employ static analysis early in the development cycle to detect and correctmemory management issues, such as buffer overflows and memory leaks, before the code is compiled.
Apply static analysis after deployment to monitor the drone's performance inreal-time and make adjustments as needed.
Rely solely on static analysis to ensure code reliability, skipping dynamictesting altogether.

questions.question_text_1: What is the key aspect of the "ethics of care" framework?
question_texts: What is the key aspect of the "ethics of care" framework?

options.option_text: Understanding and responding to the needs of others

questions.question_text_1: A CPU has 512KB of SRAM connected to it starting at address 0x00200000. What is the address of the last byte in the SRAM?
question_texts: A CPU has 512KB of SRAM connected to it starting at address 0x00200000. What is the address of the last byte in the SRAM?

questions.question_text_1: A memory-mapped peripheral has a register set starting at address 0xABCDEF00. Each register is 32 bits wide. If there are 10 registers in the set, what is the address of the 6th register?
question_texts: A memory-mapped peripheral has a register set starting at address 0xABCDEF00. Each register is 32 bits wide. If there are 10 registers in the set, what is the address of the 6th register?

questions.question_text_1: A 12-bit ADC can digitize an analog value into ___ distinct levels.
question_texts: A 12-bit ADC can digitize an analog value into ___ distinct levels.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and equations** for the **Embedded C Programming** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Microcontrollers (MCUs) vs. Microprocessors (MPUs)**
- **MCUs**: Used for **dedicated, low-power tasks** (e.g., sensor monitoring, IoT devices).
  - Features: Integrated memory, peripherals (ADC, timers, UART), low cost.
  - Example: **Temperature/humidity monitoring (Q2)**.
- **MPUs**: Used for **high-performance computing** (e.g., servers, PCs).
  - Features: External memory, higher clock speeds, no built-in peripherals.

#### **2. Embedded Programming Languages**
- **C**: Dominant for embedded systems (low-level control, efficiency).
- **C++**: Object-oriented extension of C (modularity, classes, templates).
  - Used when **abstraction** or **code reuse** is critical (Q3).
- **Assembly**: For **performance-critical** or **hardware-specific** operations (Q10).
- **Rust**: Emerging for safety-critical systems (memory safety, no garbage collection).

#### **3. Data Types & Memory Efficiency**
- **Key Data Types in Embedded C**:
  - `uint8_t`: 8-bit unsigned integer (0–255). **Most efficient for values ≤ 100 (Q4)**.
  - `uint16_t`: 16-bit unsigned integer (0–65,535).
  - `int`: Typically 16/32 bits (platform-dependent).
- **Memory Optimization**:
  - Use the **smallest data type** that fits the range.
  - Avoid `int` if `uint8_t` suffices (saves RAM/Flash).

#### **4. Analog-to-Digital Conversion (ADC)**
- **Resolution**: Number of distinct levels an ADC can represent.
  - **10-bit ADC**: \(2^{10} = 1024\) levels.
  - **12-bit ADC**: \(2^{12} = 4096\) levels (Q24).
- **Voltage Resolution**:
  - Formula: \(\text{Resolution (V)} = \frac{V_{ref}}{2^n}\)
    - \(V_{ref}\): Reference voltage (e.g., 3.3V).
    - \(n\): Bit depth (e.g., 10 bits).
  - Example (Q5): For 10-bit ADC, \(V_{ref} = 3.3V\):
    \[
    \text{Resolution} = \frac{3.3}{1024} \approx 3.22 \, \text{mV}
    \]

#### **5. Wireless Communication Protocols**
| Protocol  | Range       | Power Usage | Use Case                          |
|-----------|-------------|-------------|-----------------------------------|
| **Zigbee** (Q6) | 10–100m     | Low         | Home automation, sensor networks  |
| WiFi      | 50–100m     | High        | High-speed data (e.g., streaming) |
| LoRa      | 1–10km      | Very Low    | Long-range IoT (e.g., agriculture)|
| LTE       | Cellular    | High        | Mobile broadband                  |

- **Scalability (Q7)**: A protocol’s ability to **handle more devices efficiently** (e.g., Zigbee supports mesh networks).

#### **6. Code Optimization Techniques**
- **Loop Unrolling (Q8)**:
  - **What it does**: Reduces loop overhead by **expanding iterations manually**.
  - Example:
    ```c
    // Original loop
    for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) { sum += array[i]; }

    // Unrolled loop
    sum += array[0]; sum += array[1]; sum += array[2]; sum += array[3];
    ```
  - **Benefit**: Fewer branch instructions → faster execution.

- **DMA (Direct Memory Access) (Q14)**:
  - **Purpose**: Offloads **data transfers** from CPU to peripherals (e.g., ADC → RAM).
  - **Use Case**: Real-time audio processing (48 kHz sampling).
    - DMA transfers data **without CPU intervention**, reducing latency.

#### **7. Power Management**
- **Power Consumption Formula (Q9)**:
  \[
  P = V \times I
  \]
  - \(P\): Power (Watts).
  - \(V\): Voltage (constant in the question).
  - \(I\): Current (key factor when \(V\) is fixed).
- **Leakage Current Reduction (Q15)**:
  - **Sleep Modes**: Disable unused peripherals/components.
  - **Dynamic Voltage Scaling (DVS)**: Reduce \(V\) when possible.
  - **Clock Gating**: Turn off clocks to idle modules.

#### **8. Assembly Language Basics (Q10)**
- **Registers**: Temporary storage (e.g., AX, DX, BX in x86).
- **Key Instructions**:
  - `MOV`: Copy data (e.g., `MOV AX, 15`).
  - `ADD/SUB`: Arithmetic (e.g., `ADD AX, DX`).
  - `JMP/CALL`: Control flow.
- **Example Execution**:
  ```assembly
  MOV AX, 15    ; AX = 15
  MOV DX, 25    ; DX = 25
  ADD AX, DX    ; AX = 15 + 25 = 40
  SUB DX, 10    ; DX = 25 - 10 = 15
  ```
  Final: **AX = 40, DX = 15**.

#### **9. Device Drivers (Q11)**
- **Purpose**: Provide an **abstraction layer** between hardware and software.
  - Example: A **UART driver** hides register-level details for serial communication.
- **Key Functions**:
  - Initialize hardware.
  - Handle interrupts (e.g., data received).
  - Provide APIs (e.g., `UART_write()`).

#### **10. Error Handling & Debugging**
- **Assertions (Q12)**:
  - **Purpose**: Catch **logical errors** during development.
  - Example:
    ```c
    assert(x > 0); // Crashes if x ≤ 0 (debug-only).
    ```
- **Real-Time Debugging (Q16)**:
  - **Tools**:
    - **RTOS Debuggers**: Trace task execution (e.g., FreeRTOS + Tracealyzer).
    - **Logic Analyzers**: Capture timing signals.
  - **Avoid**: `printf` (adds latency) or manual delays (unreliable).

#### **11. Static Analysis (Q17)**
- **What it does**: Analyzes code **without execution** to find bugs.
  - **Common Checks**:
    - Memory leaks (e.g., `malloc` without `free`).
    - Buffer overflows.
    - Dead code.
  - **When to Use**: **Early in development** (before compilation).

#### **12. Memory Mapping**
- **SRAM Addressing (Q20)**:
  - **Given**: 512KB SRAM starting at `0x00200000`.
  - **Last Byte Address**:
    \[
    \text{Start} + \text{Size} - 1 = 0x00200000 + 0x80000 - 1 = 0x0027FFFF
    \]
- **Peripheral Registers (Q21)**:
  - **Given**: 32-bit registers starting at `0xABCDEF00`, 10 registers.
  - **6th Register Offset**: \(5 \times 4 = 20\) bytes (`0x14`).
  - **Address**: `0xABCDEF00 + 0x14 = 0xABCDEF14`.

#### **13. Finite State Machines (FSM) (Q22)**
- **Components**:
  - **States**: e.g., `STATE_OFF`, `STATE_ON`.
  - **Events**: e.g., `EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS`.
  - **Transitions**: State changes based on events.
- **Example (LED Control)**:
  ```
  STATE_ON --(Button Press)--> STATE_BLINKING --(Button Press)--> STATE_OFF
  ```
- **Key Rule**: Always handle **unexpected states** (e.g., `default` case).

#### **14. Real-Time Operating Systems (RTOS)**
- **FreeRTOS Basics (Q23)**:
  - **Tasks**: Independent threads (e.g., `Task1`, `Task2`).
  - **Scheduler**: Switches tasks based on priority.
  - **Critical Function**: `vTaskStartScheduler()` **must be called** to start multitasking.
- **Task States**:
  - **Running**, **Ready**, **Blocked** (e.g., by `vTaskDelay`), **Suspended**.

#### **15. Bitwise Operations (Q19)**
- **Bit Masking**: Check/set/clear specific bits.
  - **Example**: Check if the 5th bit (0-indexed from right) is set in byte `y`:
    ```c
    if (y & 0x10) { /* Bit is set */ }
    ```
  - **Mask Calculation**: \(2^{\text{bit position}} = 2^4 = 16\) (`0x10`).

#### **16. Ethics in Embedded Systems (Q18)**
- **Ethics of Care**:
  - Focus on **relationships** and **responsiveness** to stakeholders.
  - Contrast with:
    - **Utilitarianism** (maximize happiness).
    - **Deontology** (follow rules).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Embedded System Components**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Embedded System] --> B[Hardware]
    A --> C[Software]
    B --> D[Microcontroller]
    B --> E[Peripherals]
    E --> E1[ADC]
    E --> E2[UART]
    E --> E3[Timers]
    C --> F[Firmware]
    C --> G[RTOS]
    C --> H[Drivers]
    D --> I[Memory]
    D --> J[CPU]
    I --> I1[Flash]
    I --> I2[SRAM]
```

#### **2. ADC & Data Acquisition**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Analog Signal] --> B[ADC]
    B --> C[Digital Value]
    B --> D[Resolution]
    D --> D1[10-bit: 1024 levels]
    D --> D2[12-bit: 4096 levels]
    C --> E[Microcontroller]
    E --> F[Processing]
    E --> G[DMA]
    G --> H[Memory Buffer]
```

#### **3. RTOS Task Management**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[RTOS] --> B[Tasks]
    A --> C[Scheduler]
    B --> B1[Task1]
    B --> B2[Task2]
    C --> D[Priority-Based]
    C --> E[Time-Slicing]
    B1 --> F[Running]
    B1 --> G[Blocked]
    B2 --> H[Ready]
    A --> I[vTaskStartScheduler]
    I --> J[Multitasking]
```

#### **4. Code Optimization Techniques**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Performance Optimization] --> B[Loop Unrolling]
    A --> C[DMA]
    A --> D[Sleep Modes]
    B --> B1[Reduce Branch Instructions]
    C --> C1[Offload CPU]
    C --> C2[Real-Time Data Transfer]
    D --> D1[Lower Power]
    D --> D2[Disable Peripherals]
```

#### **5. Wireless Protocols Comparison**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Wireless Protocols] --> B[Zigbee]
    A --> C[WiFi]
    A --> D[LoRa]
    A --> E[LTE]
    B --> B1[Low Power]
    B --> B2[Mesh Networking]
    C --> C1[High Speed]
    C --> C2[High Power]
    D --> D1[Long Range]
    D --> D2[Very Low Power]
    E --> E1[Cellular]
    E --> E2[High Latency]
```

#### **6. Memory Layout**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Memory Map] --> B[SRAM]
    A --> C[Peripherals]
    B --> B1[0x00200000 to 0x0027FFFF]
    C --> C1[Registers]
    C1 --> C2[0xABCDEF00 to 0xABCDEF14]
```
